Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cryoneurolysis for Phantom Limb Pain

Participants.evidence: patients with lower-limb amputation and established phantom pain. Conducted at a tertiary care center

Intervention.evidence: randomised to either ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryoneurolysis or sham treatment

Objective.evidence: This study assessed the effectiveness of cryoneurolysis in reducing phantom pain.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in average phantom pain intensity from baseline to 4 months

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for investigators, participants, and clinical staff, except for the treating physician.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 144 participants were randomised: 71 to cryoneurolysis and 73 to sham.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Pain intensity decreased by 0.5 [−0.5, 3.0] in the cryoneurolysis group versus 0 [0, 3] in the sham group, with an estimated difference of −0.1 (95% CI −1.0, 0.7), P=0.759.

Harms.evidence: One serious adverse event occurred in the cryoneurolysis group due to a protocol deviation, resulting in quadriceps weakness and possibly a fall and clavicle fracture.
